sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Erythema nodosum leprosum: 100 to 200 mg ORALLY once a day for up to 3 months to facilitate corticosteroid dose reduction or elimination; taper dose to 100 mg as soon as reactive episode is controlled
  • Lepromatous leprosy: (dapsone-sensitive multibacillary leprosy) 100 mg ORALLY once a day in combination with 2 other antileprosy drugs for at least 2 years; monotherapy can be instituted when negative skin smears are obtained
  • Lepromatous leprosy, Dapsone-resistant: (dapsone-resistant leprosy) 100 mg ORALLY once a day in combination with 1 or more other antileprosy drugs for 3 years followed by monotherapy with 100 mg of clofazimine daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Not approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for use in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: hepatic impairment: severe hepatic insufficiency, consider dose adjustment; no specific recommendations available

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Erythema nodosum leprosum
  • Lepromatous leprosy
  • Lepromatous leprosy, Dapsone-resistant
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Erythema dyschromicum perstans
  • Neuropathic ulcer
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• history of gastrointestinal problems (abdominal pain, diarrhea)
  • pink to brownish-black skin discoloration; reversible but may take months to years

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Drugs for which the effect on nursing infants is unknown but may be of concern.
  • WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding. Monitor infant for side effects.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Congenital ichthyosis of skin (8% to 28%), Discoloration of skin (75% to 100%), Pruritus (1% to 5%.), Rash (1% to 5%.)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (40% to 50%.), Diarrhea (40% to 50%.), Epigastric pain (40% to 50%.), Nausea (40% to 50%.), Vomiting (40% to 50%.)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythroderma (less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Bowel obstruction (less than 1%), Disorder of intestine, Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (less than 1%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis (less than 1%)
  • Psychiatric:Reactive depression (situational), Due to skin discoloration
  • Other:Splenic infarction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Systemic: Exact mechanism unknown; has a slowly bactericidal effect on Mycobacterium leprae; inhibits mycobacterial growth and binds preferentially to mycobacterial DNA.
  • Exerts anti-inflammatory effects in the control of erythema nodosum leprosum reactions.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Systemic: Variable; Bioavailability: 70%; food increases absorption

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Systemic: Fecal/biliary: up to 50% unchanged; Renal: 1% unchanged and 0.6% metabolites; Sputum/sebum/sweat: small amounts

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in arthralgias, fever, leukocytosis, neuritis, and skin lesions
  • signs and symptoms of depression
  • signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal problems

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that drug may cause red to brownish-black discoloration of skin. This effect is reversible, but may take months or years to return to normal.
  • This drug may also cause red or brownish-black discoloration of conjunctivae, body fluids, or feces.
  • This drug may cause dry skin.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of depression (secondary to skin discoloration) or gastrointestinal problems (nausea, vomiting, bowel obstruction, gastrointestinal hemorrhage).
  • Patient should take drug with meals.
